content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Based on my risk-averse personality, I would choose a strategy that provides consistent earnings over time. In this case, since both options provide some earnings, the safer option seems to be picking 'B', as it guarantees a payoff of 40$ in each round if my partner also picks 'B'. If they pick 'R', I will still earn more (35$) than if I had picked 'R' and they chose 'B' (0$). Since the game has 75 rounds, choosing 'B' seems to be the safer choice overall. However, it's important to note that this strategy assumes that my partner also values security and will likely pick 'B' as well. If there is a chance that they might pick 'R', then the optimal strategy could change.

In this case, if I know that my opponent chose 'R' in the previous round and they seem to value the higher payout, they might be more likely to choose 'R' again in the next round. However, since I picked 'B' before and it earned me 35$, I could consider switching strategies and picking 'R' now to maximize my earnings.
